content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions about acetone, <math alttext="C 3 H 6 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math>, which is represented in the following Lewis diagram. A. The bonding in an acetone molecule can be modeled using sigma and pi bonds. Based on the Lewis diagram, identify the number of sigma bonds and the number of pi bonds. Sigma bonds: __________ Pi bonds: __________

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions about acetone, <math alttext="C 3 H 6 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math>, which is represented in the following Lewis diagram. A. The bonding in an acetone molecule can be modeled using sigma and pi bonds. Based on the Lewis diagram, identify the number of sigma bonds and the number of pi bonds. Sigma bonds: __________ Pi bonds: __________

B. While held at a constant temperature of <math alttext="800, decimal point, kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mn>800.</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></math>, a sample of <math alttext="C 3 H 6 O, gas" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="italic">g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> and a sample of <math alttext="H 2 O, gas" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> are in containers separated by a closed valve, as shown in the diagram. i. Assuming ideal behavior, constant temperature, and initial volumes of <math alttext="4.00 liters" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></math> and <math alttext="2.00 liters" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></math> for the gases shown, what is the partial pressure, in <math alttext="atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mi>atm</mi></math>, of the <math alttext="C 3 H 6 O, gas" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> after the valve is opened and the gases have mixed?

ii. After the gases mix, the system is cooled to <math alttext="400, decimal point, kelvins" overflow="scroll"><mn>400.</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></math>. What is the ratio of the acetone partial pressures, <math alttext="the fraction with numerator P sub 400 kelvins, and denominator P sub 800 kelvins, end fraction" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mn>400</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow></msub><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mn>800</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow></msub></mfrac></math>, at the two temperatures? <math alttext="the fraction with numerator P sub 400 kelvins, and denominator P sub 800 kelvins, end fraction, equals BLANK" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mfrac><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mn>400</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow></msub><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mn>800</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow></msub></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi></math>

C. After the gases are cooled to <math alttext="400, decimal point, kelvins" overflow="scroll"><mn>400.</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></math>, the measured pressure of the system is significantly lower than the predicted value, partially because of strong interactions between molecules of <math alttext="C 3 H 6 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> and molecules of <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math>. i. Draw a single dashed line <math alttext="" overflow="scroll"><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>‐‐‐</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> on the following diagram to indicate the location of the strongest interaction between a molecule of <math alttext="C 3 H 6 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> and a molecule of <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math>.

ii. Using principles of kinetic molecular theory, explain why the attraction between molecules of <math alttext="C 3 H 6 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> and <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> results in a pressure that is lower than the predicted value.

<math alttext="C 3 H 6 O, aqueous, plus I 2, aqueous, reacts in the presence of H 3 O with a positive 1 charge to produce, C 3 H 5 I O, aqueous, plus H I, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mover><mo>→</mo><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow></mover><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>IO</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>HI</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> Acetone, <math alttext="C 3 H 6 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math>, reacts with <math alttext="I 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> in acidic solution, as represented by the preceding equation. A student conducts several trials at constant temperature using different concentrations of the reactants. The results of the student’s experiment are provided in the following table. Trial <math alttext="the concentration of C 3 H 6 O, molar" overflow="scroll"><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>M</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> <math alttext="the concentration of I 2, molar" overflow="scroll"><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>M</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> <math alttext="the concentration of H 3 O with a positive 1 charge, molar" overflow="scroll"><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>M</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> Initial Rate <math alttext="(in molar per second)" overflow="scroll"><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>M</mi><mo>/</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> <math alttext="1.33" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.33</mn></math> <math alttext="0.00100" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.00100</mn></math> <math alttext="0.162" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.162</mn></math> <math alttext="8.11 times 10 raised to the negative 6 power" overflow="scroll"><mn>8.11</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup></math> <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> <math alttext="1.33" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.33</mn></math> <math alttext="0.00100" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.00100</mn></math> <math alttext="0.323" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.323</mn></math> <math alttext="16.6 times 10 to the negative 6 power" overflow="scroll"><mn>16.6</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup></math> <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> <math alttext="0.667" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.667</mn></math> <math alttext="0.00100" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.00100</mn></math> <math alttext="0.323" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.323</mn></math> <math alttext="8.25 times 10 to the negative 6 power" overflow="scroll"><mn>8.25</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup></math> D. Explain how the data in the table support that the reaction is first order with respect to <math alttext="C 3 H 6 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math>.

E. The reaction is found to be zero order with respect to <math alttext="I 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Use the data to determine the overall rate law for the reaction.

F. Using the data from trial 3, calculate the value of the rate constant, <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>, in <math alttext="inverse molar inverse seconds" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>M</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mtext>s</mtext><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>.

G. When the reaction occurs at a higher temperature, the value of the rate constant, <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>, increases. Based on collision theory, explain why the value of <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> increases with temperature.

H. The following mechanism was proposed for the reaction. Explain how this mechanism is consistent with the reaction being zero order with respect to <math alttext="I 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Step 1: <math alttext="C 3 H 6 O plus H 3 O with a positive 1 charge is in equilibrium with C 3 H 6 O H with a positive 1 charge, plus H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><msup><mtext>O</mtext><mo>+</mo></msup><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><msup><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mtext>O</mtext></math> slow Step 2: <math alttext="C 3 H 6 O H with a positive 1 charge, plus H 2 O is in equilibrium with C 3 H 5 O H, plus H 3 O with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>6</mn></msub><msup><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><msup><mtext>O</mtext><mo>+</mo></msup></math> fast Step 3: <math alttext="C 3 H 5 O H plus I 2, reacts to produce C 3 H 5 I O, plus H I" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>I</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>→</mo><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>5</mn></msub><mtext>IO</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>HI</mtext></math> fast

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
